abstract.p: Astrocytes are a class of neural cells that control homeostasis at all levels of the central and peripheral nervous system. There is a bidirectional neuron–glia interaction via a number of extracellular signaling molecules, glutamate and ATP being the most widespread. ATP activates ionotropic P2X and metabotropic P2Y receptors, which operate in both neurons and astrocytes. Morphological, biochemical, and functional evidence indicates the expression of astroglial P2X1/5 heteromeric and P2X7 homomeric receptors, which mediate physiological and pathophysiological responses. Activation of P2X1/5 receptors triggers rapid increase of intracellular Na+ that initiates immediate cellular reactions, such as the depression of the glutamate transporter to keep high glutamate concentrations in the synaptic cleft, the activation of the local lactate shuttle to supply energy substrate to pre- and postsynaptic neuronal structures, and the reversal of the Na+/Ca2+ exchange resulting in additional Ca2+ entry. The consequences of P2X7 receptor activation are mostly but not exclusively mediated by the entry of Ca2+ and result in reorganization of the cytoskeleton, inflammation, apoptosis/necrosis, and proliferation, usually at a prolonged time scale. Thus, astroglia detect by P2X1/5 and P2X7 receptors both physiological concentrations of ATP secreted from presynaptic nerve terminals and also much higher concentrations of ATP attained under pathological conditions.

sec.title: Astroglia—Homeostatic Neural Cells
sec.p: Astroglia are a highly heterogeneous (in their morphological characteristics and function) class of neural cells that provide a homeostatic system of the brain and spinal cord. Various types of astroglial cells (which include protoplasmic gray matter astrocytes, fibrous astrocytes of white matter, perivascular and marginal astrocytes, radial Müller cells in the retina, pseudo-radial Bergmann glial cells in cerebellum, interlaminar and polarized astrocytes of the primate brain, and pituicytes in the neurohypophysis [see Verkhratsky and Butt 2007; Kimelberg 2010; Kimelberg and Nedergaard 2010; Matyash and Kettenmann 2010]) control CNS homeostasis at all levels. Astroglia are central for organ homeostasis (by controlling the blood-brain barrier), morphological homeostasis (astrocytes shape the microarchitecture of the brain and support synaptogenesis/synaptic maintenance), cellular homeostasis (astroglia appear as adult neural stem cells and regulate neurogenesis), metabolic homeostasis (through supplying neurons with energy substrates), and molecular homeostasis of the interstitial space (by regulating concentrations of ions, neurotransmitters, and neurohormones). Furthermore, astrocytes (together with microglia) represent a defense system of the CNS; disturbance of neural tissue triggers evolutionary conserved programs of astrogliosis. Quite naturally, these many functions require sophisticated systems of monitoring the CNS environment and the activity of neuronal networks, these monitoring systems being represented by a multitude of receptors expressed in the astroglial plasma membrane and by several intercellular signaling cascades associated with these said receptors. Astrocytes being of neural origin are potentially capable of expressing all types of receptors to neurotransmitters and neurohormones, although the actual complement of the receptors varies considerably between different types of astroglia residing in different brain regions; conceivably, expression of receptors is controlled by an immediate neurochemical environment (Verkhratsky and others 1998; Verkhratsky and Steinhäuser 2000). It is widely acknowledged that astrocytes possess a specific form of Ca2+ excitability associated with activation of metabotropic receptors, inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (InsP3) synthesis, and Ca2+ release from the endoplasmic reticulum (Agulhon and others 2008; Verkhratsky and others 1998). The InsP3-induced Ca2+ release is often triggered in astrocytes following neuronal activity, and it provides the main mechanism for propagating Ca2+ waves in glial syncytia; these waves are considered to represent the main form of astroglial long-range signaling (Cornell Bell and others 1990; Dani and others 1992; Kirischuk and others 1995; Porter and McCarthy 1996; Grosche and others 1999; Scemes and Giaume 2006; Kuga and others 2011). Apart of the metabotropic route, astroglial cells express several types of ionotropic receptors that most likely provide for local fast signaling within the confines of the tripartite synapse. It is noteworthy that in the peripheral nervous system, astroglial cells (e.g., satellite glia of sensory ganglia, enteric glia of the enteric nervous system) exert functions indistinguishable from those of their central counterparts.

sec.title: Ionotropic Receptors in Astrocytes
sec.p: The functional integration of neural cells in the nervous system is achieved either through direct intercellular contacts (gap junctions, also referred to as “electrical synapses”) or through extracellular diffusible chemical messengers (neurotransmitters, neuromodulators, and hormones). In neurotransmission (which generally occurs at synapses), the response of the effector (or postsynaptic) cell is diversified through specific receptors that trigger excitation or inhibition in a transmitter-specific manner. Neurotransmitter receptors appear in two functional guises: metabotropic receptors coupled with intracellular signaling cascades, and ionotropic receptors being transmitter-gated ion channels that control ion fluxes, which in turn control the membrane potential. The ionotropic receptors in the nervous system are represented by three topologically different classes of ion channels (Fig. 1; Chiu and others 1999; Sobolevsky and others 2009; Browne and others 2010; Dent 2010). The most diversified class of ionotropic receptors is the pentameric channels (with each single subunit composed of four transmembrane domains), which form receptors for acetylcholine, GABA, glycine, and serotonin in vertebrates. Two other classes of ionotropic receptors are the receptors for glutamate and ATP. The glutamate-gated channels are tetrameric, and each subunit has three fully developed transmembrane domains, whereas P2X receptors are trimers and every subunit has two transmembrane domains.

caption.p: Three classes of ionotropic receptors. Purinoceptors (trimeric P2X receptors; every subunit is assembled from two transmembrane domains), glutamate receptors (tetrameric AMPA, kainate [KA], and NMDA receptors; each subunit is assembled of three transmembrane domains), and pentameric receptor channels for acetylcholine [ACh], GABA, glycine, and serotonin (each subunit is composed of four transmembrane domains). Vertebrate P2X and ionotropic glutamate receptors are non-selective cation channels, whereas pentameric receptors are either non-selective cation channels (nicotinic ACh [nACh], serotonin [5-HT3]) or chloride channels (GABAA, glycineA). The existence of Zn2+-gated pentameric cation channels is still a matter of speculation. Invertebrate tissues express a range of pentameric channels with unusual properties.

sec.p: Astrocytes in the mammalian brain have limited expression of pentameric receptors, which are restricted to GABA and glycine-gated channels (incidentally, activation of both always triggers depolarization of astrocytes because of high cytoplasmic Cl– concentration). There is no evidence for in situ astroglial expression of ionotropic nicotinic (n)cholinoreceptors or ionotropic serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine; 5-HT3) receptors. Astroglial expression of ionotropic glutamate receptors (of AMPA and NMDA subtypes) is widespread (Steinhäuser and Gallo 1996; Seifert and Steinhäuser 2001; Verkhratsky and Kirchhoff 2007a, 2007b), whereas the astroglial expression of P2X purinoceptors has begun to be characterized in detail only recently. In the present review, we concentrate on the less conventional astroglial P2X receptors involved in supporting various astrocytic functions, including neuron–glia cross-talk. P2Y receptors, which appear to be more appropriate relay stations for slow ATP signaling in astrocytes, will not be discussed, despite their equal significance for health and disease.

sec.title: P2X Receptor mRNA and Protein in Astroglia
sec.p: Although both P2X receptor mRNA and protein were found in astrocytes isolated from different areas of the brain and kept in culture (Verkhratsky and others 2009), the informative value of these results is limited because of a number of reasons: (1) RT-PCR or Western blotting does not supply any information about the source of the receptor message, which represents a serious problem because all glial cell cultures are contaminated with neurons, endothelial cells, and microglia (this problem may be evaded when the cytoplasm of single identified cells is harvested for subsequent RT-PCR). (2) Astrocytes are exceptionally plastic and are known to alter their receptor complement when surviving in vitro. (3) In immunocytochemical experiments, the presumed astrocytes are not always double-stained for glial markers such as, for example, glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) to unequivocally confirm the cellular identity.

Quantitative RT-PCR, Western blotting, and immunohistochemistry of primary cultures of astrocytes obtained from the rat cerebral cortex documented the presence of the majority (P2X1,4-7, Fischer and others 2009; P2X1-5,7, Fumagalli and others 2003) of P2X receptors. In cultured astrocyte-like satellite glial cells (SCGs) of rat dorsal root ganglia (DRGs), P2X7 receptor-immunoreactivity (IR) was detected (Chen and others 2008). Noteworthy, glial cells in culture often form a confluent monolayer at the bottom of the dish, showing a flat and polygonal morphological state very much different from the appearance of astrocytes in situ (Fischer and others 2009; Nörenberg and others 2010).

More convincingly, in acutely isolated Müller glial cells of the retina, single-cell RT-PCR identified the message for P2X3,4,5 in rats (Jabs and others 2000) and for P2X7 in humans (Pannicke and others 2000). Similarly, in astrocytes mechanically isolated from the cerebral cortex of transgenic mice that express enhanced green fluorescent protein under the control of the human glial fibrillary acidic promoter [Tg(GFAP/EGFP], mRNAs for P2X1,5 were found (Lalo and others 2008). Immunohistochemistry using specific antibodies further corroborated astroglial expression of P2X receptor proteins. In the nucleus accumbens (where all seven receptors were detected at a transcriptional level), immunofluorescence revealed co-localization of P2X2,3,4 receptors with GFAP-labeled astroglial profiles (Franke and others 2001). Staining with specific antibodies revealed astroglial expression of P2X1 and P2X2 receptors in the cerebellum (Kanjhan and others 1996; Loesch and Burnstock 1998), P2X2 receptors in the spinal cord (Kanjhan and others 1999), P2X4 receptors in the brainstem (Ashour and Deuchars 2004), and P2X1-4, P2X6, and P2X7 receptors in the juvenile hippocampus (Kukley and others 2001). It is especially interesting that both mechanical and ischemic injury led to an up-regulation of P2X2-4 receptor expression and the appearance of previously absent P2X1 and P2X7 receptor immunoreactivity in the accumbal and cortical astrocytes (Fig. 2; Franke and others 2001, 2004).

sec.title: Functional P2X Receptors in Astroglia: Identification and Properties
P2X1/5 Receptors
sec.p: In astrocytes mechanically isolated from the cerebral cortex of Tg(GFAP/EGFP) mice, ATP induced current responses with complex kinetics (rapid peak followed by a steady-state plateau) (Fig. 3A; Lalo and others 2008; Verkhratsky and others 2009). The main properties of the response to ATP (high agonist sensitivity, biphasic kinetics, absence of desensitization, sensitivity to the broad P2 receptor antagonist PPADS and to the more specific P2X1-4 receptor antagonist TNP-ATP) were similar to those reported for P2X1/5 heteromeric receptors studied previously in heterologous expression systems (see, e.g., Surprenant and others 2000). The Ca2+ permeability of astroglial P2X1/5 receptors was high and stimulation of neuronal afferents in cortical slices triggered glial synaptic currents (GSCs) and intracellular Ca2+ ([Ca2+]i) transients, as measured by the patch-clamp method and Ca2+ imaging, respectively (Palygin and others 2010). The astroglial P2X1/5 receptors are regulated by intracellular phosphoinositides (Ase and others 2010). Depletion of phosphoinositides by wortmannin decreased the amplitude of both the fast and slow P2X1/5 current components, whereas phosphoinositide 4,5-bisphosphate [PI(4,5)P2] completely rescued this effect. It was suggested that the astroglial P2X1/5 receptors are modulated by PI(4,5)P2 through the P2X1 lipid-binding domain.

sec.title: P2X7 Receptors
sec.p: P2X7 receptors are unique members of the P2X family in that they respond only to high concentrations of ATP; upon prolonged stimulation, the P2X7 receptors form a high-permeability pore that allows the passage of cations and anions with molecular weights of up to 900 Da (Sperlagh and others 2006). There is much discussion as to whether the receptor channel dilates during this process, as originally assumed (Virginio and others 1999; but for single-channel measurements see Riedel and others 2007), or whether an associated protein such as pannexin-1 (Pelegrin and Surprenant 2006) is involved in the pore opening. The P2X7 receptors were found to mediate cationic currents in acutely isolated human Müller cells of the retina but without pore formation, even after long-lasting application of the P2X7 agonist dibenzoyl-ATP (BzATP; Pannicke and others 2000). This may be attributable to the presence of a splice variant of the receptor with a missing intracellular C-terminus (Cheewatrakoolpong and others 2005).

Recently, P2X7 receptor–mediated currents were identified in cultured rodent cortical astrocytes (Fig. 3B; Duan and others 2003; Nörenberg and others 2010) and in astrocytes patch-clamped in acute brain slices of rats and mice (Fig. 4; Oliveira and others 2011). The P2X7 identity of these currents is supported by the following data: (1) BzATP was 10 times more potent than ATP itself; (2) removal of divalent cations from the extracellular media greatly potentiated the responses to ATP; (3) P2X7 receptor antagonists such as Brilliant Blue G (BBG) and A 438079 inhibited BzATP-induced currents; and (4) high concentrations of ATP failed to induce currents in astrocytes from the P2X7 knockout mice. The discovery of functional P2X7 receptors in astrocytes of the prefrontal cortex and hippocampus is somewhat at odds with the previously reported failure of ATP and BzATP to activate ion currents in hippocampal astrocytes voltage-clamped in brain slices of Tg(GFAP/EGFP) mice (Jabs and others 2007). There are at least two possible reasons for this discrepancy. First, in contrast to the prefrontal cortex, the BzATP-induced astrocytic currents in the hippocampus are minuscule, when measured in a normal Ca2+/Mg2+-containing external medium (Oliveira and others 2011), although they can be greatly increased by exchanging the normal medium to one that contains a low Ca2+ concentration with no added Mg2+. Second, the BzATP responses are also surprisingly very small in cortical astrocytes of Tg(GFAP/EGFP) mice and might have been overlooked in the hippocampus. These results are in agreement with the reported data that both BzATP and ATP activate mouse recombinant P2X7 receptors with much lower potencies than the corresponding rat receptors (Young and others 2007).

sec.p: Based on the considerable Ca2+ permeability of P2X receptors, [Ca2+]i recordings were repeatedly used to confirm the functional expression of these receptors in astroglia. Cultured cerebrocortical astrocytes responded with an increase of [Ca2+]i to a range of non-selective P2X/Y receptor agonists, with notable exception of the P2X1,3 selective agonist α,β-methylene ATP (α,β-meATP; Fumagalli and others 2003; Fischer and others 2009). Based on these data, the conclusion was made that P2X7 receptors represent the main pathway for Ca2+ entry, although astroglial P2Y receptors may also contribute to the ATP- or BzATP-induced [Ca2+]i transients (Fumagalli and others 2003; Nobile and others 2003). A relatively weak point in this argument was that only the slowly acting, irreversible, and non-specific P2X7 antagonist, oxidized ATP (Sperlagh and others 2006), was used in these experiments to confirm the P2X7 receptor identity. A more detailed analysis was carried out in cultured cerebellar astrocytes, where BzATP elicited a biphasic response (Carrasquero and others 2009). The first phase of this response was due to the release of Ca2+ from intracellular stores and was mediated by P2Y13 receptors, whereas the second phase was, arguably, due to the influx of Ca2+ from the extracellular medium via P2X7 receptor-channels. Pretreatment with pertussis toxin (which inhibits G protein–coupled P2Y13 receptors) and pharmacological inhibition with the P2Y13-selective antagonist MRS2211 depressed the early phase of [Ca2+]i response to BzATP. Conversely, removal of external Ca2+ and exposure to BBG decreased the delayed portion of BzATP-induced [Ca2+]i transient, suggesting the role for P2X7 receptor.

sec.title: Astroglial P2X Receptors: Association with Signaling Cascades
sec.p: P2X receptors are archetypal ligand-gated cationic channels, equally permeable to Na+ and K+; their permeability to Ca2+ is as a rule higher than that to monovalent cations (PCa/Pmonovalent varies between ~2 and 10 depending on the subunit composition; Pankratov and others 2009). In astrocytes, which typically have a resting potential ~ −80 to −90 mV and which resist depolarization because of high resting K+ permeability (Verkhratsky and Steinhäuser 2000), activation of P2X receptors triggers influx of Na+ and Ca2+.

Nucleotides were reported to initiate a wide range of second-messenger signaling cascades leading to long-term trophic changes in astrocytes (Franke and others 2006; Neary and Zimmermann 2009; Burnstock and Verkhratsky 2010). These actions, mediated mostly through P2Y receptors, include the induction of proliferation, stellation, and migration. There is increasing evidence that growth factor receptors such as those for fibroblast growth factor-2 (FGF2), epidermal growth factor (FGF), and nerve growth factor (NGF) can be transactivated by P2 receptor activation (Abbracchio and others 2006). In addition, P2Y receptors, through G protein-coupling, stimulate mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) cascades, involving the extracellular signal-regulated protein kinases (ERKs), the stress- activated protein kinases c-Jun N-terminal kinases (JNKs), and p38/MAPKs (Franke and others 2009; Neary and Zimmermann 2009). Another P2Y receptor–dependent protein kinase cascade is the phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K/Akt) pathway, which promotes in astrocytes cell survival/growth and inhibits apoptosis (Neary and Kang 2005; Franke and others 2009).

Interestingly, extracellular ATP appears to exert a dual effect on astroglial proliferation by P2Y/P2X7 receptor activation. In primary cultures of astroglial cells, low concentrations of ATP enhanced DNA synthesis caused by FGF2, whereas high concentrations inhibited FGF2-induced proliferation (Neary and others 2008). BzATP mimicked high ATP concentrations, whereas uridine triphosphate (UTP) mimicked the effect of low ATP concentrations. It was concluded therefore that P2X7 and P2Y receptors produce opposite regulation of the FGF2-induced proliferation of astrocytes. The lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-stimulated release of tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α) from astroglial cultures also appeared to be under the dual control of P2X7/P2Y receptors, because high and low concentrations of ATP inhibited and facilitated the release of TNF-α, respectively (Kucher and Neary 2005). The weak point of these authors’ arguments is that BzATP is not a truly selective agonist of P2X7 receptors, and as long as selective antagonists are tested, the evidence presented remains circumstantial. The same criticism can be applied to the reported P2X7 receptor–dependent activation of protein kinase C (Hung and Sun 2002) and phospholipase D (Hung and others 2005) in the astrocytic cell line RBA-2, where only BzATP was tested as an agonist. In contrast, the BzATP-stimulated Akt phosphorylation in rat cortical astrocytes was antagonized by BBG, which unequivocally identifies the receptor involved as P2X7 (Jacques-Silva and others 2004).

sec.title: Neuron–Glia Interaction
sec.p: Glial cells, and in particular astrocytes, are active players in ATP and glutamate signaling in the brain (Bezzi and Volterra 2001; Fellin and Carmignoto 2004; Fellin and others 2006; Fields and Burnstock 2008). ATP and glutamate coordinately activate astrocytes through the mobilization of their internal Ca2+ or the influx of Ca2+ from the extracellular space, which in turn triggers the release of several neuroactive molecules including ATP and glutamate themselves from astrocytes. Once astrocytes are activated, they provide both excitatory and inhibitory effects on neighboring neurons. Through the Ca2+-dependent release of glutamate, which acts on extrasynaptic NMDA receptors, astrocytes excite neurons, whereas in contrast ATP released from astrocytes, after a delayed conversion to adenosine, causes neuronal inhibition (Fellin and others 2006).

The neuron–astrocyte cross-talk is by no way limited to the CNS. Enteric glia, which outnumber enteric neurons by 2:1, stain for the astrocytic marker GFAP (Jessen and Burnstock 1982; Rühl 2005). They release ATP, which triggers the intercellular propagation of Ca2+ waves between enteric glial cells, and Ca2+ wave–induced ATP release was shown to elicit neuronal responses (Zhang and others 2003). The ectonucleotide NTPDase2 is exclusively localized to the membranes of enteric glia, suggesting that the latter controls the availability of ATP, UTP, and their derivatives (Braun and others 2004). Release of ATP from enteric glia has also been proposed to produce a feedback system for interstitial cells of Cajal to modulate slow-wave activity (Burnstock and Lavin 2002). Immunohistochemical studies showed expression of P2X7 (Vanderwinden and others 2003) and P2Y4 receptors (Van Nassauw and others 2006) on enteric glial cells, which both may be involved in Ca2+ signaling (Gulbransen and Sharkey 2009). A recent paper claims that ATP released from sympathetic nerves activates enteric glia (Gulbransen and others 2010).

sec.title: Activation of Astrocytic P2X Receptors in Response to Nearby Neuronal Activity
sec.p: Although extracellular ATP usually increases [Ca2+]i in astrocytes by P2Y receptor activation, which is typically a slow process, more recently rapid synaptic responses mediated by astrocytic P2X1/5 receptors were identified (Lalo and others 2011a, 2011b). The geometry of neuronal–glial contacts, which determine the spatiotemporal parameters of interactions between neurotransmitters and astroglial receptors, is highly heterogeneous. In general, astroglial receptors can be activated either by neurotransmitter released from presynaptic terminals (which may act directly on glial membranes in the synaptic cleft or distantly through spillover) or by ectopic neurotransmitter release. Usually, the leading mechanism for neurotransmitter release to astroglial membranes was associated with spillover (see Lalo and others 2011b), although data indicating direct synapse-like/synaptoid contacts between neurons and astrocytes are accumulating.

In the pituitary gland, stimulation of afferent nerves evoked typical GABAA and dopamine D2 receptor-mediated postsynaptic responses in stellate glial cells (pituicytes) (Mudrick-Donnon and others 1993). The noradrenergic synapse-like structures were identified in septohippocampal astrocytes (Milner and others 1995). The synaptic-like GABA/glutamatergic contacts between neuronal terminals and NG-2 glial cells are found in several brain regions; electrical stimulation of afferent nerves triggers fast postsynaptic currents in NG2 glia that result from quantal release of neurotransmitter (Paukert and Bergles 2006; Gallo and others 2008). The synaptoid contacts in which presynaptic vesicles reach neuronal terminals closely apposed to astroglial membranes were identified in the hippocampus. Electrical stimulation of Schaffer collaterals in acute hippocampal slices triggered GABA-mediated excitatory synaptic currents (EPSCs) in a subpopulation of astrocytes; the same astrocytes also demonstrated spontaneous synaptic currents (Jabs and others 2005).

ATP is a fast neuro-neuronal transmitter in the peripheral and central nervous system (Burnstock 1972, 1976, 2007; Köles and others 2007; Abbracchio and others 2009). A quantal release of ATP-stimulating ionotropic P2X receptors has been described in cultured rodent spinal and hypothalamic neurons by means of the patch-clamp method (Jo and Schlichter 1999; Jo and Role 2002). A more detailed investigation of the spontaneous quantal ATP release onto hippocampal CA1 neurons in a slice preparation indicated that although spontaneous miniature (m)EPSCs due to the secretion of ATP, glutamate, and GABA could be measured in the presence of tetrodotoxin, these transmitters are stored in distinct sets of synaptic vesicles (Pankratov and others 2006). Separate mEPSC populations could be differentiated both by altering the holding potential and by using pharmacological blockers of NMDA, AMPA, GABAA and P2X receptors. At a holding potential of -80 mV, the glutamatergic mEPSCs had higher amplitudes than the ATPergic ones and were sensitive to a combination of the AMPA and NMDA receptor antagonists CNQX and D-AP5, respectively. By contrast, in the presence of the ionotropic glutamate receptor antagonists (plus picrotoxin to exclude GABAA receptor–mediated synaptic potentials), the P2X receptor antagonists PPADS or NF279 abolished the residual small amplitude mEPSCs, indicating their ATPergic nature.

A similar picture emerged when stimulation of neuronal afferents in the same preparation evoked GSCs in astrocytes situated in layer II of the somatosensory cortex in slices obtained from the Tg(GFAP/EGFP) mouse brain (Lalo and others 2011c). Nerve stimulation–induced GSCs were gradually depressed by the sequential application of blockers for excitatory amino acid transporters of the EAAT1-5 types (TFB- and DL-TBOA) and AMPA, NMDA, and P2X receptors, in a similar manner as described for neurons (see above). In the presence of all antagonists, GSCs were blocked almost completely, indicating that they were mediated primarily by P2X and ionotropic glutamate receptors, with only a minor contribution of glutamate transporters (Lalo and others 2011a, 2011c). The spontaneous glial miniature (m)GSCs in the same preparation consisted of separate populations of slow (NMDA, AMPA) and fast (P2X) synaptic currents, which could be inhibited by appropriate pharmacological antagonists (Lalo and others 2011c). It is interesting to note that the P2X and NMDA components were the smallest in young, maximal in adult, and once more small in old mice. By contrast, the AMPA component was the largest in young animals and progressively declined with age Lalo and others 2011c).

sec.title: Transmitter Release from Astrocytes by P2X Receptor Activation and Modulation of Nearby Neurons
sec.p: Stimulation of astrocytes by chemical agents as well as by mechanical or osmotic stimuli may release ATP by four alternative mechanisms (Illes and Alexandre Ribeiro 2004): first, by exocytotic vesicular release; second, by ATP-binding cassette (ABC) proteins such as the multidrug resistance–associated protein; third, by osmolitic transporters linked to anion channels; and fourth, by diffusion through hemichannels such as unpaired connexin (Cx) channels (Illes and Alexandre Ribeiro 2004; Qu and Dubyak 2009).

Connexins and gap junctions play a fundamental role in Ca2+ wave propagation in astrocytic networks (Cotrina and others 1998). The gap junction channels provide a conduit for the movement of the Ca2+-mobilizing second messenger InsP3 from one cell to the other (Braet and others 2001). Alternatively, the single cell under stimulation releases (ether by diffusion through hemichannels or by regulated exocytosis) an extracellular signaling molecule (ATP and/or glutamate), which then activates Ca2+-mobilizing receptors in nearby cells (Stout and others 2002). The Ca2+-mobilizing purinoceptors usually belong to the P2Y class, although P2X7 is also supposed to be involved in this process (Suadicani and others 2009). The exocytotic transmitter release from astrocytes, in contrast to neuronal terminals, depends on the release of intracellular Ca2+ rather than on the influx of Ca2+ from the extracellular space. Although cultured astrocytes express at least some of the molecules required for the exocytotic release of glutamate or ATP itself (Haydon and Carmignoto 2006), and refined biophysical methods confirmed exocytosis from astrocytes in culture (Bowser and Khakh 2007), more recently the operation of such a mechanism in vivo was questioned (Hamilton and Attwell 2010). Interestingly, lysosomes rather than synaptic-type vesicles were suggested to be the storage and release sites of ATP and glutamate in astrocytes (Zhang Z and others 2007). In fact, selective lysis of lysosomes abolished both ATP release and Ca2+ wave propagation in astroglial syncytia.

An alternative mechanism of transmitter release from astrocytes can be associated with P2X7 receptors. It has been shown that P2X7 receptors provide a route for excitatory amino acid release from mouse astrocytes (Duan and others 2003). Such a release was induced by BzATP more potently than by ATP, amplified in Ca2+/Mg2+-free medium, and blocked by PPADS or oxidized ATP. In hippocampal brain slices of rats, ATP appeared to activate P2X7 receptors on astroglial cells, causing the release of glutamate, which in turn triggered a tonic current in CA1 pyramidal neurons (Fellin and others 2006). However, this effect appeared to depend on the area of the brain investigated, because it did not occur within layer V of prefrontal pyramidal neurons after stimulation of the neighboring astrocytes by BzATP (Oliveira and others 2011). The P2X7 receptors were also reported to induce GABA release from the RBA-2 astrocyte cell line through a Cl–/HCO3–-dependent mechanism (Wang and others 2002).

In mixed neuronal/astrocytic cultures, in brain slices, and in in vivo experiments, a further complicating factor is that P2X7 receptors were suggested to be present also at nerve terminals, facilitating exocytotic transmitter release (Anderson and Nedergaard 2006; Sperlagh and others 2006). It was repeatedly reported that P2X7 receptor immunoreactivity is expressed at excitatory nerve terminals of the spinal cord and the brain. However, the specificity of antibodies for this receptor has been questioned by observations demonstrating a pseudo-immunoreactivity for P2X7 receptors in hippocampal sections of the respective knockout mice, whereas the pseudo-immunoreactivity was absent in peripheral organs, such as the submandibular gland (Kukley and others 2004; Sim and others 2004). It has to be noted that the pseudo-staining detected in P2X7-deficient mice indicates only that the antibody recognizes a protein in the brain, which is not identical with P2X7 receptors; this finding by no way excludes the existence of neuronal P2X7 receptors. Moreover, it has been demonstrated that a functional P2X7 splice variant with an alternative transmembrane domain 1 escapes gene inactivation in P2X7 knockout mice (Nicke and others 2009). Thus, the existence of neuronal P2X7 receptors cannot be excluded, especially when a number of criteria are kept in mind in functional studies, such as the higher agonist potency of BzATP than that of ATP, the inhibitory effect of highly selective antagonists such as BBG and especially A 438079, and the rigorous testing of agonists/antagonists/allosteric modulators/divalent cations differentiating P2X7 from the residual P2X receptors (Anderson and Nedergaard 2006; Sperlagh and others 2006). Admittedly, a more likely explanation for the P2X7 receptor–triggered neuronal release of transmitters is a sequence of events when astrocytic P2X7 receptors secrete a signaling molecule onto neighboring neurons, which then release their own transmitter as a response to this stimulus (see later).

sec.title: Modulation of Transmitter Availability by Astrocytic P2X Receptors
sec.p: What is the role of P2X receptor–mediated fast signaling in the perisynaptic astroglial processes? It seems unlikely that relatively small currents mediated by P2X1/5 receptors in cortical astrocytes can depolarize astroglial membranes. At the same time, however, they can produce extremely localized and fast influx of Na+ and Ca2+, which may significantly alter the local transmembrane distribution of these ions (Fig. 5; Lalo and others 2011b). Local Ca2+ signals can result in many actions from focal exocytosis to local stimulation of ATP production following mitochondrial accumulation. Increase in the cytosolic Na+ may also have several functional consequences. First, it results in rapid regulation of the glutamate transporter that is directly governed by the transmembrane sodium gradient. In this scenario, rapid Na+ influx can transiently limit glutamate transport, thus keeping high glutamate concentration in the synaptic cleft at the very peak of the synaptic transmission event. Second, increase in cytosolic Na+ activates the Na+/K+ pump and therefore initiates the local lactate shuttle, thus supplying active synapses with energy substrate. Third, an increase in [Na+]i triggers reversal of the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger stimulating additional Ca2+ entry, which adds to the local Ca2+ signal.

caption.p: Physiological roles of P2X receptors in astroglia. P2X receptors are rapid entry pathways for Na+ and Ca2+ into the cell. In astrocytes, where the high membrane potential leads to a large driving force for the entry of Ca2+, which in conjunction with the high conductance of the P2X receptor for Ca2+ causes rapid increases in [Ca2+]i, focal exocytosis to release neurotransmitters (glutamate, ATP) as well as local stimulation of ATP production following mitochondrial accumulation is expected to occur. In addition, rapid Na+ influx depresses the glutamate transporter to keep high glutamate concentrations in the synaptic cleft, stimulates the local lactate shuttle to supply energy substrate for neurons, and reverses the Na+/Ca2+ exchange to stimulate additional Ca2+ entry into the cell. TCA = tricarboxylic acid cycle; lact = lactate; pyr = pyruvate.

sec.p: Activation of P2X7 receptors in astrocytes may also affect glutamate homeostasis in the synaptic cleft by modulating glutamate transport. BzATP decreased the Na+-dependent glutamate uptake mediated by the glutamate/aspartate transporter GLAST into RBA-2 cells within minutes (lo and others 2008). The decrease was augmented by the removal of extracellular Mg2+ or Ca2+ and was restored by oxidized ATP. Similarly, in a rat primary culture of astrocytes, the ability of astrocytes to take up glutamate and GLAST mRNA levels were significantly decreased after exposure to ATP and BzATP (Liu and others 2010). The inhibitory effects on mRNA expression were antagonized by oxidized ATP or when P2X7 mRNA expression was reduced by the lentivirus short hairpin RNA knockdown approach. The mechanisms may involve either local changes in [Na+]i as described above or alternative, hitherto unknown signaling pathways.

sec.title: Pathophysiological Roles of Glial P2X Receptors
Pain Sensation
sec.p: Although it can be assumed that many neuronal functions are indirect and are due to or modulated by astroglial P2 receptors and the subsequent release of further signaling molecules, this was hitherto unequivocally demonstrated only for the peripheral and central sensation of pain. In sensory ganglia, a specific type of astrocytes termed satellite glial cells (SGCs) wraps the neurons (Hanani 2010; Villa and others 2010). BzATP evoked inward current both in small diameter dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons and in SGCs (Zhang and others 2005). Investigations with the selective P2X3 receptor antagonist A317491 demonstrated that the effect of BzATP in SGCs but not in neurons was resistant to this antagonist. On the basis of the failure of A317491 to act and the Mg2-dependent blockade of the BzATP-induced current responses, it was suggested that the non-neuronal cells possess P2X7 receptors that indirectly influence the function of the pain-sensing DRG neurons. In accordance with this idea it was found that P2X7–/– mice developed neither mechanical allodynia nor thermal hyperalgesia in inflammatory and neuropathic pain models, whereas normal nociceptive processing remained (Chessel and others 2005; Jarvis 2010). The above proposal was further corroborated by the use of pharmacological antagonists of P2X7 receptors (A740003, Honore and others 2006; A 438079, McGaraughty and others 2007) demonstrating a dose-dependent reduction of both allodynia and hyperalgesia in several animal models of neuropathic and inflammatory pain (Villa and others 2010).

Two recent publications reported that activation of SGC P2X7 receptors signals back to DRG neurons and leads (through the modulation of P2X3 receptors) to modified pain sensation. Acutely dissociated DRG neurons released ATP upon electrical stimulation as measured by the sniffer patch-clamp technique (Zhang X and others 2007). The released ATP stimulated P2X7 receptors of the SGCs, which in turn released TNF-α; this cytokine potentiated P2X3 receptor–mediated responses in neurons, thus increasing their excitability. Another group of researchers, however, reported opposite results (Chen and others 2008). In this latter study, P2X7 receptors of SGCs tonically inhibited the expression of P2X3 receptors on DRG neurons. Reducing P2X7 receptor expression by using siRNA or pharmacological blockade of P2X7 receptors resulted in up-regulation of P2X3 receptors, increased the susceptibility of sensory neurons to painful stimuli, and evoked abnormal nociceptive behavior in rats.

Interestingly, inflammation was reported to induce a large increase in the sensitivity of SGCs to ATP (determined by Ca2+ imaging), which involved a switch from P2Y to P2X receptors (Kushnir and others, 2011). In these experiments, 7 days after the induction of submandibular inflammation in mice with complete Freund’s adjuvant, SGCs of trigeminal neurons were prepared and transferred to short-term cultures. It appeared that after inflammation, the responses to ATP were largely due to P2X2 and/or P2X5 receptor activation. It was proposed that the augmented sensitivity of SGCs to ATP after injury may contribute to chronic pain states.

The sensation of pain is subjected to descending control from the CNS, such as the mid-pontine nucleus locus coeruleus (LC), containing a dense population of noradrenergic neurons (Stamford 1995). LC neurons in a rat brain slice preparation were superfused with a Mg2+-free and bicuculline-containing external medium (Khakhpay and others 2010). Under these conditions, BzATP slightly facilitated the amplitude of spontaneous mEPSCs and strongly potentiated their frequency. PPADS and BBG as well as selective metabolic poisoning of astrocytes (fluorocitric acid, aminoadipic acid) prevented the effects of BzATP. It was suggested that the stimulation of astroglial P2X7 receptors leads to the release of a signaling molecule, which presynaptically increases the spontaneous release of glutamate onto LC neurons from their afferent fiber tracts.

The P2X3 receptor agonist α,β-meATP triggers long-term potentiation in rat dorsal horn spinal cord slices (Ikeda and others 2007), which is believed to be related to persistent pain during peripheral inflammation (Sandkühler and Liu 1998). This potentiation was inhibited by fluoroacetic acid, suggesting the contribution of glial cells.

sec.title: Do P2X Receptors Control Astroglial Proliferative Response following CNS Damage?
sec.p: In vivo studies showed that focal cerebral ischemia by occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery (MCAO) leads to the release of ATP into rat striatal microdialysate (Melani and others 2005). At the same time, mechanical injury to the rat nucleus accumbens elevated the concentrations of both ATP and glutamate in the microdialysate (Franke and others 2006). The local increase in ATP concentration may lead to the up-regulation of the enzyme chain hydrolyzing extracellular ATP, which tends to decrease the overtly high levels of this nucleotide (Braun and others 1998). It was concluded that ATP may exert an excitotoxic action, thereby causing the death of previously uninjured neurons and astrocytes in the penumbra surrounding the necrotic tissue of the core area of ischemically or mechanically damaged nervous tissue.

In parallel to increased ATP levels in the CNS after mechanical trauma or ischemia, both P2X and P2Y receptor types were time-dependently up-regulated on rat astrocytes with an approximate maximum of 4 days post lesion (Franke and Illes 2006). It was expected that these receptors would be down-regulated during their activation by high agonist concentrations; however, both in vivo and in vitro studies unequivocally documented their higher expression in the cell membrane, probably due to the release of further extracellular signaling molecules (cytokines, reactive oxygen species, cysteinyl leukotrienes) by the cellular damage itself or the resulting transmitter release (e.g., Ciccarelli and others 2004; Mason and others 2004; Clark and others 2010). A further reason may be an increased integration of P2X/P2Y receptors into the plasma membrane during cellular trafficking after oxygen/glucose deprivation (for P2X7 receptors, see Milius and others 2007).

As mentioned previously, immunohistochemical investigations in the nucleus accumbens of rats showed that after stab wound injury, the previously absent P2X1 and P2X7 receptor immunoreactivity was observed in GFAP-positive astrocytes (Franke and others 2001). Similar findings were reported for the cerebral cortex of spontaneously hypertensive rats, where MCAO led to the up-regulation of P2X7 receptor IR in the penumbra surrounding the necrotic region (Franke and others 2004; see also Fig. 2). This immunoreactivity was co-localized with astrocytic markers; immunoelectron microscopy revealed the expression of P2X7 receptors on presynaptic elements of glial cells. In support of a secondary damage caused by ATP-induced stimulation of P2X (probably P2X7) receptors in the penumbra, both suramin and PPADS reduced the infarct volume and accelerated functional recovery in behavioral tests (Kharlamov and others 2002; Lämmer and others 2006, 2011).

Purines (in particular ATP and adenosine) act as neuro- and gliotransmitters in the sensory retina, where they are involved in bidirectional neuron–glia signaling (Housley and others 2009; Wurm and others, 2011). Activation of P2X7 receptors at human Müller cells results in membrane depolarization, calcium influx from the extracellular space, sustained activation of Ca2+-activated, big conductance K+ (BK) channels, and probably calcium release from thapsigargin-sensitive intracellular stores (Bringmann and others 2001). The P2X7 receptor–induced depolarization of the cell is balanced by the hyperpolarization caused by potassium flux through the BK channels. In Müller cells from patients with proliferative vitreoretinopathy, the mean density of the BzATP-induced cationic currents was significantly greater when compared with cells from healthy donors. As a consequence, such cells displayed an enlarged IBK during application of purinergic agonists.

An interesting question relates to the second-messenger mechanisms coupled to the respective P2X receptors activated by nucleotides subsequent to neuronal/glial damage. A rapid increase of intracellular Ca2+ and the subsequent activation of Ca2+-dependent enzymatic pathways appear to be the primary mediators of immediate and long-term cellular changes. As partly discussed earlier, P2X7 receptor channels react to long-lasting exposure to high ATP concentrations by (1) opening the large membrane pore; (2) reorganizing the cytoskeleton, leading to membrane blebbing; (3) releasing proinflammatory cytokines such IL-1β; and (4) activating caspases to trigger apoptosis, contributing as a whole to the necrotic/apoptotic actions of the nucleotide (Fig. 6; Sperlagh and others 2006; Di Virgilio 2007). The delayed proliferative effects of ATP are due primarily to P2Y receptor activation, although P2X7 receptor may also be involved.

caption.p: Pathological role of P2X7 receptors in astroglia. P2X7 receptors activate caspase-1 as an apoptotic enzyme and initiate the cleavage of pro-interleukin-1β to interleukin-1β (IL-1β). In addition, cytoskeletal changes occur, leading to membrane blebbing. Both P2X7 receptors themselves and connexin hemichannels function as exit pathways for glutamate and ATP. P2X7 receptor stimulation via the [Ca2+]i-induced transactivation of second-messenger pathways coupled to P2Y receptors causes cell proliferation and inflammation. sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Although mRNA and protein for various types of P2X receptors have been found in astrocytes, functional studies indicated the presence of P2X1/5 heteromeric and P2X7 homomeric receptors only, the former ones mediating fast synaptic signals and the latter ones long-term necrotic/apoptotic as well as proliferative reactions. Whereas the existence of neuronal P2X7 receptors is much disputed, it is quite clear that astrocytic P2X7 receptors may release signaling molecules acting at nearby neurons and thereby indirectly mediate seemingly neuronal effects. It is most likely that in the near future, many P2X7 effects that have been attributed to neurons will turn out to be, in fact, of astrocytic origin.
